conclusion: Consider initial direction of A, positions of blocks, and effects of collisions and deflections.
A is initially positioned near the bottom right corner of the image, facing towards the left.
A is moving towards the left, so it will first encounter the blue block directly in its path.
After colliding with the blue block, A may be deflected depending on the angle and force of the collision.
A collides with the blue block. Assuming a standard collision, A might be deflected slightly upwards or continue straight depending on the block's resistance.
If A continues straight after the collision, it will next encounter the orange block directly ahead.
If deflected upwards, A might collide with the green block above the blue block.
After colliding with the orange block, A might stop due to the combined resistance of the blocks.
Alternatively, if deflected upwards, A might stop after hitting the green block.
Primary Collision: A will collide with the blue block first.
Secondary Collision: Depending on the deflection, A might then collide with either the orange block or the green block.
Final Stop: A will likely stop after the second collision, either near the orange block or the green block.
A will collide with the blue block first, then either the orange block or the green block, and will eventually stop near one of these blocks.
